titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Rudolph Dunbar Papers
titlestmt.author: by Afua Ferdnance

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday March 26, 2019 at 03:05

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Rudolph Dunbar Papers document the professional activities of clarinetist, conductor, music critic, teacher and journalist Rudolph Dunbar. Series in this collection include Correspondence, Professional Papers, Photographs and Other Papers. Among those represented in the correspondence series include Coretta Scott King, Eslanda Robeson, and British parliament member Robert Allan. Professional papers include press releases, German propaganda of African Americans during World War II, and music programs from Dunbar's performancesas a music conductor. Photographs of independence day celebrations of former British colonies in Africa and the Caribbean make up a large portion of the photographs alongside highlights of Dunbar's music career as a conductor and teacher. Photographs also include dignitaries and celebrities of the day such as Kwame Nkrumah, Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Phillip and Jesse Owens.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Correspondence, 1938-1977 II. Professional Papers, 1944-1984 III. Photographs, 1940-1975 IV. Other Papers, 1963-1986.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Rudolph Dunbar was born on April 5, 1899 in Nabacalis, British Guiana (now known as Guyana). Dunbar's birthdate is uncertain as he gave various dates throughout his career. However, records show that his actual birthdate is April 5, 1899 according to the Danish Immigration Office file V. 76420 of March 1929, and various ship passenger lists. Dunbar held many positions throughout his life including clarinetist, music critic, orchestra conductor, music teacher and journalist. Dunbar began his musical career as a clarinetist in 1912 while in the British Guiana Militia band. He later moved to the United States in 1919 to study music composition, piano, and clarinet playing at the Institute of Musical Art (Now the Julliard School). After graduation, Dunbar continued his musical education in France, Germany, and Austria. He studied music composition with Paul Vidal, clarinet playing with Louis Cahuzac as well as conducting with Phillip Gaubert and Felix Weingartner. In 1931, Dunbar created the Rudolph Dunbar School of Clarinet Playing in London, England. In 1942, he became the first musician of African descent to conduct the London Philharmonic Orchestra at the noted Royal Albert Hall in London, England. Other noted orchestras Dunbar conducted include the Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra, and the Berliner Philharmoniker Orchestra. Dunbar was also the London correspondent for the Associated Negro Press and reported information of Great Britain during World War II. A journalist throughout his life, he also documented the independence of several African and Caribbean countries from British colonial rule. Dunbar continued his career as a musician and journalist until his death in London, England on June 10, 1988.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Rudolph Dunbar Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Rudolph Dunbar Papers document the professional activities of clarinetist, conductor, music critic, teacher and journalist Rudolph Dunbar. Series in this collection include Correspondence, Professional Papers, Photographs and Other Papers. Among those represented in the correspondence series include Coretta Scott King, Eslanda Robeson, and British parliament member Robert Allan. Professional papers include press releases, German propaganda of African Americans during World War II, and music programs from Dunbar's performancesas a music conductor. Photographs of independence day celebrations of former British colonies in Africa and the Caribbean make up a large portion of the photographs alongside highlights of Dunbar's music career as a conductor and teacher. Photographs also include dignitaries and celebrities of the day such as Kwame Nkrumah, Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Phillip and Jesse Owens.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Rudolph Dunbar Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Former call numbers: JWJ MSS Small Collections, Uncat JWJ MSS Rudolph Dunbar, JWJ Zan Dunbar, R., 1979 Folio 79, and 1984 Folio 26.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by last name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the professional correspondence of Rudolph Dunbar. Letters regarding Dunbar's music performances such as those at the Royal Albert Hall and the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra are in this series. Many letters from British parliment member Robert Allan also document Dunbar's trials in securing steady work as a music conductor in a field that included few people of African descent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials that document Rudolph Dunbar's music and journalism career. Items such as his personal press passes, press releases and music programs are in this series. Also included from Dunbar's work as a news correspondent during World War II are excerpts of Nazi German war propaganda against African Americans. Journals detailing the schedule of British ceremonial state visits to African countries such as Kenya, Nigeria, Tanzania and Zaire are also contained within this series.

did.unittitle: Martin Sullivan's address for the late Martin Luther King Jr.
Memorial service for Martin Luther King
Norman Washington Manley Memorial Service Program
President of Nigeria State Visit to the United Kingdom

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ephemera from the former Nigerian President Alhaji Shehu Shagari's visit to the United Kingdom in 1981. A transcript of a speech given by President Alhaji Shehu Shagari is also included.

did.unittitle: Sir Alexander Bustmante memorial service program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs, scrapbooks and news clippings that document Rudolph Dunbar's career as a journalist, music conductor, teacher and critic. Photographs include independence day celebration of African and Caribbean countries from British colonial rule. Dignitaries depicted within this series include former Ghanaian president Kwame Nkrumah, Queen Elizabeth II Prince Phillip of England and Jesse Owens.

did.unittitle: Indepence celebrations of former British colonies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Other Papers series includes ephemera collected by Rudolph Dunbar throughout his career.
